title: Drug gang’s drone downs police helicopter targeting cocaine crops
description: Colombia’s president describes the mid-air attack, which killed 12 officers, as an act of ‘terrorism’
content:
FARC dissidents, who rejected a 2016 peace deal with the government, and the Gulf Clan are both active in Antioquia and heavily involved in cocaine production.

Authorities said the helicopter was transporting police officers as part of an operation to destroy coca leaf crops, the raw material for cocaine.

Mr Petro said an alleged member of the dissident group was arrested in the area of the explosion.

Andres Julian, the governor of Antioquia, said a drone attacked the helicopter as it flew over coca leaf crops. The attack is thought to have caused a fire onboard.

In Cali, unknown attackers threw two cylinder bombs at Marco Fidel Suárez military airbase, which exploded on the busy street.

“Cali is once again the victim of a narco-terrorist attack,” said Alejandro Eder, the mayor of Colombia’s third-largest city, which is close to the violent region of Cauca.

In March, FARC dissidents launched eight simultaneous attacks across Cauca, including motorcycle bombs and drones carrying explosives, which is a region with many coca crops on a major drug trafficking route.

Mr Petro travelled to Cali after the attack, which he said came after FARC dissidents had suffered a defeat at the hands of the military.

He said on X that one of the perpetrators had been detained in Cali, where two people were killed in explosions in June.

“Terrorism is the new expression of the factions...which have submitted to the control of the drug trafficking junta,” he said, adding that the government “asks the world to consider the drug trafficking cartel as a terrorist organisation.”

Mr Eder has offered a reward of £74,000 for information leading to the capture of those responsible for the attack on the airbase. Another £74,000 was offered by regional authorities.

Colombia’s Ministry of Defence said it would offer rewards of up to £37,000 for anything information allowing them to “anticipate any terrorist attack in the country.”
summary: A drone attacked a police helicopter carrying police officers in Antioquia, Colombia, as it was transporting them as part of an operation to destroy coca leaf crops, the raw material for cocaine. The incident occurred after FARC dissidents rejected a 2016 peace deal with the government and the Gulf Clan, both of which are involved in cocaine production. The attack is believed to have caused a fire onboard the helicopter. The mayor of Cali, Alejandro Eder, has offered a reward of £74,000 for information leading to the capture of those responsible for the attack. The Colombian government has also offered rewards of up to £37,000 to anticipate any terrorist attack.
shortSummary: A drone attack by FARC dissidents on a police helicopter in Antioquia resulted in a fatal explosion, prompting a reward for information.
argos_summary: FARC dissidents and the Gulf Clan are active in Antioquia, Colombia, where a helicopter transporting police officers was attacked by a drone while conducting operations against coca crops. The governor of Antioquia reported the incident, which resulted in a fire on the helicopter, and an alleged dissident was arrested nearby. In a separate incident, two cylinder bombs were detonated at a military airbase in Cali, prompting local authorities to offer rewards for information on the attackers, as the region continues to face violence linked to drug trafficking.
